Fields.DialogueText: Any slower and the frost will get you before the Morganas do.
I'm doing a routine inspection of the ship, Saguenay. I'd prefer to take my time with that.
Routine, eh? An artifact of your naval training. Bien. That can be unlearned.
Hm. A few crew members mentioned you had an impatient streak.
Is it impatience not to want to fall behind the pack?

Fields.MenuText: Why don't you stop and smell the roses for a while?
I understand, but could you please calm down?
Carry on, then!

Fields.DialogueText: Luxury is the most insidious of poisons. It strikes at the soul.
That sounds suspiciously like falling behind.
I try. The crew have quite a way to go before I deem them a pack.
I'm going to go back to my inspection now. I can only handle so much intensity at one time.
You won't be rid of me so easily. There are Morganas who need to be taught un leçon!
Hard to tell if they're learning. They just keep coming.
Some lessons take longer than others.
@BATTLE
Saguenay! I have a few tasks I need you to do.
What is it, Capitaine?
I need you to deliver this message to the first mate, swab the deck, and organize our food supply.
I'm on it.
Okay. Lieutenant, can you get me-
Finished, Capitaine. What else needs doing?
What? Those things were supposed to take all day! How did you finish them so quickly?
I just did them. The deck is clean, the message has been delivered, and the food is in order. Do you have anything else for me to do?

Fields.MenuText: No, that was really it. You can relax now, I guess.
I've half a mind to have you help with the crew's duties... but I'm not actually going to make you do that.
You can be captain of the ship if you want. You're obviously more qualified.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll find work for myself. There's no point in sitting around when there are endless possibilities to keep myself busy.
Good. It wouldn't do to teach them indolence.
Don't tease me now, Capitaine. I have my place in the pack, and you have yours.
If you really want to do something, how about you lead the fight against those Morganas I see approaching?
Crouched to spring, Capitaine. So are the crew, I'm pleased to report. It seems my cleaning spree lit a fire under them.
@BATTLE
Attendez! Capitaine, don't throw those out.
What, the bones? I'm done with lunch, Saguenay.
Give them to me. I need to read them.
Read them.
Intel has been spottier for this patrol than I'd like. I'm filling in the blanks.
With chicken bones.
A porcupine or a hare would be more ideal, but... eh, ça fera.

Fields.MenuText: If you want to root around in my scraps, be my guest.
What's the difference?
Navy food is navy food. We don't generally eat like that.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't make it weird, Capitaine.
Hush, Capitaine. Let me see...
Any port in a storm. Now step back.
How's this supposed to work?
Give me your lighter.
All yours.
Hmm... there! See that burn mark? The path to the Morganas we seek should be ten degrees... that way.
Ah, this one will do.
You're certain?
Humour me, Capitaine. My senses will vindicate me.
@BATTLE
I need the entire crew to general quarters! We have Morganas on the horizon!
You heard the Capitaine! Action stations!
@BATTLE
Just as the bones predicted.
So you say.
You don't have to take my word for it.
I'm going to have to, much as I'd like to test out your... methods.
I know when I'm being patronized.

Fields.MenuText: You're not being patronized. I know Belles have resources I don't... untraditional as they may be.
No, I mean it. I don't think it'd be proper for the captain to resort to superstition.
Bone reading, Saguenay? That's fantasy stuff.

Fields.DialogueText: Then put your money where your mouth is.
What luck! This is no mere superstition.
The technical term is scapulimancy, and it's as real as I am.
What would the crew think if they saw me burning bones to plot our patrol courses?
They'd probably think you odd. Maybe even crazy.
Maybe they'd think the Belle was corrupting me with her heathenry.
They'd be right before long. I wouldn't have chosen a capitaine I couldn't corrupt.
The Morganas beat you to it. One of them's already called Corruption.
Oh, I know. It's a poor hunter that doesn't learn a thing or two from their prey.
I need everyone to gather around me! The lookouts just spotted a group of incoming Morganas, but they're acting a little... odd.
Hmm. They have the numbers, but they're not pressing their advantage. A surprise attack from a force we've yet to detect?
It very well might be. We just need to be prepared for the worst. Everyone, stay alert.
You know, Capitaine, we really ought to plan some surprise attacks of our own. We could humiliate these Morganas into submission.

Fields.MenuText: I don't think Morganas feel shame.
Just as long as we don't sink to their level.
I'd certainly like to. They're just so elusive...

Fields.DialogueText: They don't. But they have a crippling addiction to pride. We can use that.
Ha! Agreed, Capitaine. Their level is at the bottom of the ocean.
Even the waves record tracks if you know what to look for.
Hmm... yes, I'm sensing more astern. I'm impressed, Capitaine. Your instincts were correct.
You mean we're surrounded!? Damn it. We need to-
-Escape, Capitaine. I agree. But we should make this escape as painful as possible for the trappers.
We're not lingering any longer than we need to.
No need. A wounded moose can yet thrash.
I'm not sure how I feel about being compared to a moose.
You've obviously never met one.
Have you?
... In a sense. It's a Belle thing.
@BATTLE
I'm feeling less than my best. I worked through breakfast to finish this after action report.
Franchement? There are only so many words for "victory."
Yes, yes, we're amazing. I'm still hungry.
You're lucky I always smoke a little extra meat. Take this.

Fields.MenuText: It's yours. I couldn't possibly.
Yes, please. I owe you one.
What's the special today? Caribou jerky?

Fields.DialogueText: It is mine to dispose of as I wish. Unless you'd prefer I force-feed you.
You need your strength. I need your strength. The Morganas only engage when they are strongest. So should we.
At sea? Don't be ridiculous. I stole some beef from the galley and rubbed it in coffee. It's the next best thing.
I'll take it. Thank you, Saguenay.
@BATTLE
You're looking less than your best, Capitaine.
Think nothing of it. The crew need you, and so do I.
It'll definitely get me through the next little while. Though a banana would really wake me up...
Bad luck aboard a ship, Capitaine.
You and your superstitions. I'll bite. Why?
That'll have to wait, Capitaine. I've scented some prey.
To the bridge, then. Could I trouble you for some more-
I gave you what you needed. Make it work.
We've spotted some Morganas heading in from the east! Prepare for battle!
@BATTLE
Saguenay, I need to talk to you about that last engagement.
I was just going to find you to commiserate. One of these days we'll destroy them for good.
No, no. It's not that. You're just a rough fighter, and some of the crew were injured as a result during that last battle.
Oh, yes, the ones in the infirmary. They were in the wrong place at the wrong time.
That's not really an exc- wait. You knew?
I take a clear shot if I have it. They're just stunned.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe you could take a less active role in future battles until you figure it out?
Remember that the crew is on your side, and when they're at their healthiest, you are too.
Enough. It can't be this dangerous to serve aboard you.

Fields.DialogueText: Out of the question. We can't afford to fight with our limbs tied.
Then let me teach them how to be better.
Once their senses are as honed as mine, it won't be.
You Belles can function autonomously, but I draw the line at endangering our crew.
It's a question of trust, Capitaine. I can read signs and situations and interpret them. Would you not act accordingly in my place?
We can't run this war on your superstitions.
Right where we want them!
Then to hell with trust. You and the crew must learn to see as I do.
I'll humor you. But humor me: no unilateral weapons fire until your lessons have been learned.
You drive a bitter bargain. I like that in a colleague. I accept.
What have I gotten us into?
Capitaine! Come quick!
Is it the Morganas again?!
No, there are some beluga whales out there! Look at them! Aren't they adorable?
I suppose.
You suppose? What's your favorite kind of animal, then?

Fields.MenuText: I've always been more of a fan of orcas.
I really like albatrosses. It's amazing that something so huge can fly.
I prefer polar bears. They've been known to eat belugas, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah. Their fiercest predator. I can respect that... however difficult.
Truly majestic creatures. Bad luck to kill one, too. In them's the souls of sailors.
When they're trapped in ice. Hmm. A land animal, defeating a sea creature when opportunity strikes... I see your connection.
I never would have expected you to be this passionate about wildlife, Saguenay.
Belugas are just so interesting, so serene. J'aime les baleines.
So what do they represent?
Represent?
@BATTLE
Isn't there some kind of meaning in their formation or something?
Ah. Non, Capitaine. I simply wanted to point out something cute.
That's... uncharacteristically nice of you.
Nature is brutal. That doesn't mean it can't be beautiful.
Though if you insist on a deeper meaning... the pod of belugas is going that way because it's in the opposite direction of our Morganas.
I could have told you that.
Thank you, Saguenay. It's... a doll?
Innikueu. A tea doll, to others.
You made this? The stitching is so fine.
All the better to keep the tea inside. I'm giving these to the whole crew.

Fields.MenuText: Are they used for anything else?
What's this have to do with learning your superstitions?
We should get together and have tea sometime in the future.

Fields.DialogueText: Stress relief. Companionship. Even when the tea's run out, they can be a calming influence.
Consider it a foundation. Learn where I come from and you'll be better equipped to see the world as I do.
Exactly my goal. We'll never be far from a cup.
You carry one too, don't you?
I do! Hold it and see.
Oof. This one's heavy.
4.7" shells will do that.
What!?
Don't drop it, Capitaine! I keep this one for emergencies.
@BATTLE
For you, Capitaine.
Where do you even keep this thing?
Don't think about it too hard, Capitaine. It'll distract you from the real work that needs doing. Here they come...
I know of the basics.
En effet. It looks like we're going to have to start from scratch.
I always thought it was just a saying. It rhymes and that's it.
All right. Matthew 16: 2-3: "When it is evening, ye say, it will be fair weather: for the sky is red. And in the morning, it will be foul weather today: for the sky is red and lowering.

Fields.MenuText: You've memorized the Bible?
What's that got to do with anything?
Amen.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank the missionaries in my lands, Capitaine. Or blame them, depending on your perspective.
Weather hasn't changed in two thousand years. Back then they were looking for the same things we should.
Be serious, or I'll 2 Kings 2:24 you.
I never took you for the religious type.
Jesus isn't the only game in town. I'm trying to show you where history can repeat itself. Now, then... ah, merde. Do you see that?
@BATTLE
Now, then... you already know the basics. "Red sky in morning," and all that.
These Morganas are getting pretty repetitive.
W-weather generally moves west to east, and at s-s-sunset...
Yes?
I'm sorry, is there a reason this lesson's happening out here?
I find this weather refreshing. It's only un peu froid.
I can see my breath.
That is how you know you are alive.

Fields.MenuText: You're certainly doing your best to correct that.
I guess it's not that bad...
At least let me build a fire.

Fields.DialogueText: Pour l'amour de Dieu. I'm not even trying.
Not that bad? It's liberating!
Easy, now. We haven't gotten to scapulimancy yet.
Come on. The faster the lesson sinks in, the faster we can get back to the bridge. A little chill sharpens the mind.
At... At s-s-sunset, the light shines through heavy air... In the m-m-morning, a r-r-red sunrise means the air's passed.
@BATTLE
Once more, Capitaine. Take your time.
Meaning?
There's a storm coming!
Correct! And not a moment too soon; it looks like we've got company. Your lesson was well learned. We'll make a hunter of you yet.
I f-f-feel more dangerous already.
Capitaine! There are Morganas ahead!
Prepare for battle, everyone!
@BATTLE
Merde. We're not out of the woods yet.
What's wrong? Are there more Morganas?
No, no, it's not that. It's the clouds.
What about them?
"If a cloud looks as though scratched by a hen, get ready to reef your topsails then."
I'm sorry, what? What in the world does that mean?
Bad winds are coming.

Fields.MenuText: Another superstition?
Do you really think this could be true?
We don't have any topsails to reef.

Fields.DialogueText: It's all to do with cloud patterns. I'll explain later.
I'm almost certain, and that's the best we're going to get.
Honestly. You take everything so literally.
What do we need to do?
Get everyone below decks! I'll deal with the rest.
Get to your stations, everyone! We have Morganas headed this way!
@BATTLE
Capitaine, j'ai une triste nouvelle à te communiquer...
Bad news? Is this another superstition? The last one wasn't even right.
"Mackerel sky, not twenty-four hours dry." Do you know what this means?
I have a feeling you're going to tell me, regardless of how I answer.
There's a storm coming. A big one.

Fields.MenuText: I can't believe you on this one. Not after last time.
Saguenay, I need more proof than that.
I can't risk not believing you.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you prepared to stake our well-being on that?
Look at those wispy clouds overhead! The mare's tail! It's science, Capitaine, not just superstition. You can't deny science.
So please help me prepare!
Fine, I'll have the officers notify the crew.
Thank me later. And consider this our lesson for the day.
Saguenay, I've been meaning to ask you something. Why are you so superstitious?
Considering the storm raging outside, it would seem obvious, oui? I'm superstitious because my superstitions are valid.
It was that one time! The other time you were completely wrong!
Well, apart from that... I suppose my superstitions just offer some sort of certainty concerning the future. I like having that certainty.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe not knowing exactly what will happen, but being ready for whatever does.
Even if said reassurances aren't reliable?
The unknown isn't always for the faint of heart.

Fields.DialogueText: That's the real measure of a hunter. It's knowing how to read a hostile world.
They're reliable enough that they prepared us for this storm.
That's why you prepare for the unknown in whatever way you can.
Have the weather ones run their course, then?
Not remotely. But I think by this time you know what to look for.
I'd like to see that, I really would. Throw that one at the Morganas, will you?
@BATTLE
Imagine if I'd been right.
I suppose I can't fault you for caution. And there's scientific basis for some of it.
Strange clouds. Got it.
... I can always make another of these tea dolls.
I think this is the first time I've ever been to your cabin.
It certainly won't be the last. I'll put some tea on and break out the smoked meat.
I thought you didn't like to share your food.
In the heat of battle, no more than is necessary. In peacetime I share everything with my guests.
That's very generous of you. So what's the lesson today?
What would you like to know?

Fields.MenuText: Where do your superstitions come from?
Are all your superstitions scientific in nature, or is there magic involved?
Have you made any of your own superstitions?

Fields.DialogueText: The world over, really. England, France, Nitassinan... those I'm best versed in, but some are universal.
It's not magic if you understand it. Unless you think of magic as interacting with the spiritual realm, and even that has its own rules.
Sometimes I pick up on certain patterns and continue them for my benefit. I try to eat an apple before every battle, for instance. It's not quite the same.
Your Christianity doesn't interfere with any of it?
Why would it? It has its place and my other beliefs have theirs. Eating an apple before battle is one that brings me peace of mind.
Now, where can I find an apple...
Capitaine! The Morganas have returned! Come quick!
Good instinct.
@BATTLE
Practice, Capitaine. You just have to know what to look for.
You really enjoy the cold weather, don't you?
I'm sorry, what?
I always seem to find you out here when it's coldest outside.
These cold temperatures... they make me think of my heritage. I've never seen the Saguenay river with my own eyes, you know, Capitaine?
One day... I hope I'll be able to.
I'm sure that must be difficult; considering a place to be such a part of you, and yet not having been able to set foot on it yourself. I'm sorry.
Non, don't apologize. I'm not sure how, but I'm hopeful.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad to hear it.
You really think you'll be able to?
If the chance ever presents itself, rest assured I'll do my best to help make it happen.

Fields.DialogueText: Hope must begin where certainty ends.
I don't know. I think that's the point of hoping.
That's so kind of you, Capitaine. Thank you.
I'll be here if you ever need anything.
Thanks, Capitaine. You know, you're enduring this cold much better than you used to.
Maybe it's your naturally warm demeanor.
@BATTLE
Enjoy it, Capitaine. I only show it to those I like.
Better hide it, then. I think we've got Morganas.
I dreamed as much. I'll meet you on the bridge.
... Dreamed?
Sleep rests the body. The spirit does... its own thing.
Hmm... I see...

Fields.MenuText: ... a cloud that looks like a beaver.
... a flock of seabirds. Aren't they supposed to be good luck?
... a whole lot of water.

Fields.DialogueText: I've... never seen a beaver like that.
They can be. Or they can be lost souls from less fortunate crews.
Astutely observed.
You're the one who knows all these old wives' tales.
They're old for a reason, Capitaine. Legends... superstitions... religion... they stick around because they bring clarity. Understanding. Comfort.
And sometimes they get the weather right.
Indeed. I'm not telling you what to look for, Capitaine. The important thing is that you look.
What am I looking for?
Why are you asking me?
All right, Capitaine, tell me what you see.
The skies, the seas, and all the things that live in them... an observant soul hears what they're saying, and listens where they know they must learn.
Like when their Belle is being mysterious.
See? You're picking this up quickly enough.
Huh... do you feel that chill, Saguenay?
Morganas.
I knew it. Care for an apple?
@BATTLE
Saguenay, what is that you have pinned on your dress? It looks different from the rest of the accessories you have.
Viking trefoil.
Why in the world do you have that?
Same reason as I have anything, Capitaine. Remind me after the battle to tell you about it.
@BATTLE
So, that trefoil...
Valknut, technically. I'm afraid you might be expecting a grander story than what I have to tell you. I found it buried in the mud below the ship when last we made port.
I've always had an affection for these brooches.

Fields.MenuText: How long did it take you to find that? How long were you underwater?
Do you have any idea what it means or where it might've come from?
Ha, you were right. I was expecting a grander story.

Fields.DialogueText: It didn't take long, trust me. Having the ability to phase certainly helped matters.
A little of one, but that's part of the charm.
Oh, quiet, you. I know you're just jealous.
What's it mean?
It's not really clear. Some say it's a symbol of Odin; others, that it's meant to guide one to the afterlife.
I wonder if the Vikings had Belles.
Ha! If they had they'd still be around today.
The Germans do call you Walküren. Especially the propagandists.
They would. They don't interpret so much as decree.
No, the thing itself is much more interesting to me than how I found it.
We can't know which meaning is true. So I choose to believe they all are, in their own way.
Convenient.
Respectful.
Rough waters today.
Oui. I've got a bad feeling about today's Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: Did you try eating an apple?
There's nothing we can't face down.
What kind of bad feeling?

Fields.DialogueText: I did. Now I am more awake to experience my bad feeling.
I know. But even the strongest of creatures can be felled.
Malaise, Capitaine. I can't put my finger on the source.
I don't know what to tell you, Saguenay, except that we're all in this together.
There. I suppose it's in His hands now.
Whose?
God's, of course. Whose else?
@BATTLE
... Saguenay?
Just when I think I'm beginning to understand you...
Sailor! Hum or be quiet.
He was just whistling, Saguenay.
He mocks the wind. I shouldn't have to explain to you why that's a bad idea at sea.

Fields.MenuText: Have you seen it happen before?
This is getting out of hand.
It's not like we have to worry about sails.

Fields.DialogueText: Non. But some things you dare not risk.
These things don't care if you believe in them or not.
It's the principle of the thing.
What's going to happen? We'll be blown over?
Forgetting something can make it all the more powerful.
I said I'd humour you, Saguenay. But this is getting ridiculous. It used to be bad luck to have women on board, too. That's been forgotten for obvious reasons.
Because men were stupid. I do as I do because nature is vengeful.
More vengeful than the Morganas?
Times change, Capitaine, but some things stay stubbornly in place. And some we must force to change. You will learn the difference.
@BATTLE
Capitaine? I have a bad feeling in the pit of my stomach... you know what that means!
The Morganas are back to ruin another perfectly fine day? Yes, yes, I do.
@BATTLE
Another glorious victory from on high.
Was that what that was earlier?
The Lord's Prayer. You've seen me at it before.
I guess I'm just having trouble reading you.
How's that?

Fields.MenuText: Don't you have to pick one religion or the other?
Why all the superstitions if you have God on your side?
It's like your beliefs keep changing with the winds.

Fields.DialogueText: How very monotheistic an idea.
Well, if I called on Him for everything He'd just be another tool.
If you don't go with the wind, it will wear you down.
Look at it this way, Capitaine. I'm a daughter of many lands: English-built, Canadian-bred, Iroquois-named.
"Saguenay" is... Iroquois? Not Innu?
Long story. I feel the presence of the Lord as closely as the Mishtapeuat. I talk to one when I want to be closer to the earth. I talk to the other when things get... less concrete.
I think I get it. The sailor superstitions have their own place in all this too.
Nutauinan tshin uashkut ka tain...
... The hell?
... Tshima it. All right, let's go.
About the only wrinkle is that God is jealous. But that's His problem.
Awfully warm out today.
I think it's a nice change.
Nature is beautiful in all its colors. I'm just reminded of more lax times.
It'd be a shame not to be able to appreciate a nice day.
The Caribbean. The South Pacific. Pah. The explorers that described paradise were looking for ease and indolence. Living so you barely know you're alive.

Fields.MenuText: Hard to appreciate a sunny day otherwise.
What's paradise to you, then?
A lot of the other Belles seem to like it.

Fields.DialogueText: There's a certain extra bitterness to the cold on a clear winter's day. I live for it.
Bathing in snowmelt. Tracking your next meal through the rocks and moss and burning its bones to point the way to the next.
A lot of the other Belles wouldn't last a week in the Bay of Fundy, never mind the Labrador Sea.
I'm sorry, Capitaine. I didn't mean to ruin your mood.
Don't worry about it. I didn't realize you felt that strongly about the weather.
How do you stand it, Capitaine? It isn't right.
Nature isn't right or wrong. It just... is.
It's not a statue to be gawked at. We have our place in it, as all creatures have theirs. It's ours because for everything we take, we give back.
I mean, you don't see a squirrel or a deer sitting in a chair, sipping cold drinks and... why are you laughing?
The image.
... Get us closer to the Morganas there on the horizon. Words are failing me today.
@BATTLE
Here's your... bag of bones.
What's wrong, Capitaine?
I'm still skeptical about this... what did you call it?
Scapulimancy. It's quite simple, Capitaine. You use your senses for the physical and commune with spirits for the spiritual. It's not so different from prayer.

Fields.MenuText: By burning bones.
Don't let the crew hear you say that.
I think I get it. It's like praying to your spirits.

Fields.DialogueText: You're such a materialist. If you don't get over that, we'll never get anywhere.
This world is meant to be shared. It's not my fault some of you haven't gotten the memo.
With a little less hierarchy.
Borrow my lighter again. Let's see how this works.
Actually, Capitaine... I thought I'd give you a shot at this.
Yes. I'll vouch for you. Now light it.
While you're holding it?
@BATTLE
All right, Capitaine, I hope you saved your scraps from dinner.
Me? Wouldn't the spirits... I don't know, wouldn't they rather talk to you?
It'll take more than a flame to make me uncomfortable.
All right, that's enough. Look at the burn marks, Capitaine. What do you see?
It's... huh. Is that... a boat?
And some spots. Fetch me a chart. I think I can interpret this. Now, the boat should augur a good hunt...
Morganas, dead ahead!
It'll have to wait.
That's fine. This battle may be the frame of reference we need.
Capitaine? Are you awake? I made you une tasse de thé.
A cup of tea? That was very sweet of you. Is it the tea from your tea doll?
No, just regular tea. No gunpowder in this.
Certainly tastes like gunpowder. Mmm... but it's just what I needed. Thank you.
Is it made to your liking? I smoked one of the dolls this morning.

Fields.MenuText: It's good. I wonder if some honey might not cut the smoke.
Is the doll okay?
Perfect. This should keep me awake.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll keep that in mind for next time.
Airing out. It would have been an ill omen if it had caught fire.
Without tiring you out later. Tea has a certain balance about it.
Do you want me to read your tea leaves?
You read tea leaves, too?
Not really, not as much as I do other things. But I think "reading" them can be kind of fun.
Well, then, by all means.
It looks like... une ancre! An anchor! That's a symbol of safety for the sailor, and a sign of good and loyal friends.
That's the sort of prediction I like hearing.
Capitaine! The Morganas are back! We need to act fast!
I guess the part concerning safety was incorrect... surprise, surprise. Let's go, Saguenay.
All I did was predict the future, Capitaine. We've still got to earn it.
@BATTLE
I think that chart was a good call, Saguenay. I've been comparing this... bone... against it.
You'll get used to it, Capitaine. It's just another way of seeing the world.
Don't tell the crew this. I've set our course for where the next scorch mark corresponds to.
Stow it. It's a routine patrol. We can afford to improvise.
That felt... different.
I'll say. I feel like a wizard.
Nothing magical about it, Capitaine. It's navigation using different tools. And that wasn't even what I was talking about.
I've noticed it too. The crew seem more relaxed lately.
I think they're learning too, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: We couldn't do it without you.
You'll have to up the stakes, then. It's getting downright cozy here.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, Capitaine! It's what I'm here for.
Challenge accepted, Capitaine. Be careful what you wish for...
What have you learned?
No zealot like the convert, eh, Capitaine?
Well, if my senses are any indication... you've chosen correctly.
@BATTLE
They're learning to stay out of your way. And not to whistle.
